snippet: Through social media, Jason Russell did in mere days what diplomats and academics have tried to do for decades: draw attention to the abuses of Joseph Kony and his Lord’s Resistance Army in Uganda.
abstract: Jason Russell, using social media, has drawn enormous amount of attention to the abuses of Joseph Kony and his Lord’s Resistance Army in Uganda; since being posted, Russell's video, KONY 2012, has attracted more than 50 million views and has generated hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations; critics point out that it is not until halfway through the video that it is noted that the war he describes is no longer happening in Uganda, but that it has moved to other, more fragile countries.

byline.original: By JOSH KRON and J. DAVID GOODMAN
byline.contributor: Josh Kron reported from Kampala, and J. David Goodman from New York. Rob Davis contributed reporting from San Diego.

lead_paragraph: Through social media, Jason Russell did in mere days what diplomats and academics have tried to do for decades: draw attention to the abuses of Joseph Kony and his Lord’s Resistance Army in Uganda.

headline.seo: Ugandan Rebel, Kony, Soars to Topic No. 1 in Online Video
headline.main: Online, a Distant Conflict Soars to Topic No. 1
